It's my understanding that the one drug that really reacts worst with prescribed medication is alcohol. So we should be moving towards a drug control system that treats alcohol as just another drug.  This is especially important for depression, for which alcohol seems to be the number one drug for self-medication across most of the country.

From my own experience, my drug use absolutely stemmed from a need to self-medicate. If we had a decent mental health system that was accessible to everyone THAT may actually be something that would lower the rate of drug abuse. You have to treat the underlying cause. Laws don't really mean jack when you're addicted to something. I don't wish the anguish of drug addiction on anyone- it's truly horrible.

Integrating drug treatment within the health care system makes a lot of sense, especially when diseases like depression are involved.  Prescribed medication doesn't work as well, is my understanding, when other substances are being used, and without attention to the depression, self-medication with substances may occur.

So what happens is that European employers have stopped hiring.  Unemployment among the young in Europe is high and even when faced with a recovery employers are less likely to hire more workers.  Employers lack flexibility to fire employees (it is expensive and cumbersome process) when they are unproductive or in an economic downturn and therefore are reluctant to make additional hires even in good times.  The strong workers' rights will end up dooming it's younger generation.

I live and work in Austria. As soon as I announced my pregnancy, I could not be fired. I started maternity leave 8 weeks before my due date and was fully paid those 8 weeks and 12 weeks after delivery. I then received a generous stipend and of course free health insurance for the next 2 (!) years when I had the option of returning to work full or part-time. Our unemployment rate is 4.4%. It is not true that treating families humanely leads to an economic downturn or high unemployment.
DMV74: But there they have universal health care not linked to employment.

This story just makes me sad -- it's simply unimaginable anywhere outside the U.S. apart from a third world country. All other advanced industrialized nations have universal healthcare so workers do not fear losing their healthcare along with their jobs.

It's also much harder for workers in those other countries to lose their jobs in the first place -- Europeans have strong unions and workers' rights and employers are not able to arbitrarily fire like this.

Hey Noma, thanks for that excellent link to the Grant homepage! That one page told me more about Grant, as a person, than I've previously known.

I think the unappreciated Grant is a victim of 2 things. First, his modesty and low key approach. He was the direct opposite of a self promoting blowhard like Custer.

Second, the Puritan Ethic. Though I'm a direct descendant of a fairly prominent Puritan, Deacon John Doane, I think the Puritans caused more problems for America than almost any other group.

This phony thinking has plagued America ever since and, in my opinion, was part of the deeply flawed thinking regarding the war on drugs. Grant was constantly ridiculed for drinking, despite his historic victories and his basic saving of our union. Alcohol, of course, is a legal, addictive, hard drug, but has avoided those labels. Most people, my self included, enjoy a drink or two, and have no problem with it. The problem drinkers are another matter all together.
Winston Churchill, another savior at a key time, was also a legendary drinker.
There was a special documentary on PBS a while back by his granddaughter regarding a tour of America Churchill took as a young man in the early 20th century. It was during prohibition, but Churchill ignored the laws and toured America with his own secret stash of booze.

With the ghastly carnage, confusion, and stress Grant dealt with on a daily basis during war, you'd think people would have cut him a break and bought him a drink.

Just finished posting a photo of Grant's birthplace from last summer on the Yankee Heritage facebook page -- and what do I find? This lovely, sensitive, slide show. Indeed, Grant's personality is one of the most complex in all history. As you certainly know, Sherman said it would be a thousand years before Grant was understood. I take encouragement in thinking that we have only 870 more years to go.

At present, I'm working on my own little study called "Understanding Ulysses S. Grant," trying to aid in the effort to understand this underappreciated, underestimated, and misunderstood American hero -- who has so much to teach us about life's challenges and possibilities.

I was startled to see him described as "crude." Rather, I believe his associates and even former enemies found him exceptionally sensitive and thoughtful.
http://www.granthomepage.com/intparker.htm

I note that one photo is missing in this series, which would tell us much more about Grant: the caption over his tomb: "Let Us Have Peace." In stark contrast to the bloodbaths of 19 century Europe, Grant's peace at Appomattox was exemplary. As president, he established the first Geneva peace conference to avoid war with England. After his presidency, he helped negotiate peace between China and Japan, avoiding a war over the Rykyuyu Islands.

As he explained to Otto von Bismarck upon being invited to a military review, "Actually I take no interest in military affairs. I'm more of a farmer than a soldier."

@Mitra "Black" as a classifier of people in the US is not based in color science; it is a name given by whites to the people of Africa and by extension to the slaves. No one in the world is truly black, they are at best very dark brown. Neither is brown in America a term of colorimetry; it is a name given by whites to the native populations of North America.

Indians from India lie outside these cultural constructions.

As for the science,

http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/media/106500/The-global-distribution...

the native populations of peninsular India have the same constitutive pigmentation levels (melanin content of unexposed skin regions measured by reflectometry) as the native populations of West Central Africa where the American slaves came from. Most of central India has the same levels as Algeria and Mexico, and only Kashmir and Northern Punjab match the pigmentation of the native populations of the southern US.

Furthermore, as you will see here:

http://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/38568440/admixture/shriver01.pdf

most African-Americans have 20% admixture of European ancestry as a result of the cruelties of slavery and are on average lighter skinned than their distant cousins in West Central Africa.

Why then have Indians, whose average pigmentation is the same as the average of west central and northwest Africa, and no lighter than that of African Americans, chosen to call themselves brown rather than black?

As an Indian, why does the author consider himself brown and not black?

"Brown" in America, as in Big Bill Broonzy's song meant Spanish. There is no history of calling South Asians brown (except by Richard Rodriguez). The Bengali Muslim men, who are the subject of
Vivek Bald's book identified with blacks and married women who were then considered black in American society.

Says Bald, "Bengali Muslims quietly became part of some of America’s most iconic neighborhoods of color, from Tremé in New Orleans to Detroit’s Black Bottom, from West Baltimore to Harlem. Many started families with Creole, Puerto Rican, and African American women.

So, again, where is the author getting the notion that he is brown? There is little history in America of considering Indians brown. In fact the US Immigration Service use to consider them Caucasian until recently. I would wager that if melanin content in the skin is what is being considered, the average Indian is closer to black in America than brown.

Might it have to do with the author's Hindu cultural background (even if he claims a more hyphenated cosmopolitan identity now) and Hinduism's traditional anxiety about status and hierarchy?

Barack Obama for example is lighter skinned than most Indians and he considers himself black, as do Mariah Carey, Beyonce, Rihana, Sindbad, Colin Powell, Susan Rice, who are lighter skinned than all Indians, with a handful of exceptions.
